intro.description: This cheat sheet will automatically launch wizards, perform actions, and guide you through the individual steps to create a standalone SWT Java application using the Java Development tools. To learn more about using cheat sheets click help (?). To start this cheat sheet, click the "Click to Begin" button.

item.title: Open the Java Perspective
item.description: Select Window->Open Perspective->Java in the menubar at the top of the workbench. This step changes the perspective to set up the Eclipse workbench for Java development. You can click the "Click to Perform" button to have the "Java" perspective opened automatically.

item.title: Add SWT projects to your workspace
item.description:
1. Select "Import..." from the File menu.
2. Select "External Plug-ins and Fragments" in the Import wizard and click on the "Next" button.
3. Select "Import As Binary projects" and make sure the target platform is correct. Click on the "Next" button.
4. Select org.eclipse.swt and org.eclipse.swt.<ws>.<os>.<arch> and click on the "Add" button. (<ws>,<os>, and <arch> should be replaced with the values for the platform you wish to run against. eg. org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86).
5. Click on the "Finish" button.

item.title: Configure the SWT projects
item.description:
1. Select org.eclipse.swt in the Package Explorer.
2. From the right mouse menu, select "Properties".
3. Click on "Java Build Path" and then click on the "Libraries" tab.
4. Click on the "Add Jars..." button.
5. Select org.eclipse.swt.<ws>.<os>.<arch>/org.eclipse.swt.<ws>.<os>.<arch>_3.1.0.jar and click on the "OK" button.
6. Expand org.eclipse.swt.<ws>.<os>.<arch>_3.1.0.jar in the Libraries tab and select "Native library location".
7. Click on the "Edit..." button.
8. Click on the "Workspace..." button in the "Native Library Folder Configuration" dialog.
9. Select org.eclipse.swt.<ws>.<os>.<arch> and click on the "OK" button.
10. Click on the "OK" button in the "Native Library Folder Configuration" dialog.
11. Click on the "Order and Export" tab in the "properties for org.eclipse.swt" dialog.
12. Place a check against org.eclipse.swt.<ws>.<os>.<arch>_3.1.0.jar.
13. Click on the "OK" button.

item.title: Create a Java project
item.description: If you already have a Java project in your workspace that you would like to use, you may skip this step by clicking the "Click to Skip" button. If not, select File->New->Project... and choose Java Project in the list. Complete the subsequent pages as required. The "New Java Project" wizard is automatically displayed when you click the "Click to Perform" button.

item.title: Configure the Java project
item.description: Select your Java project and from the context menu select Properties. Select the Java Build Page and then click on the Projects tab and click on the Add button. Place a check beside org.eclipse.swt and click on the OK button to close the dialog.

item.title: Create the HelloWorld class
item.description:
1. Select File->New->Class to open the New Java Class wizard.
2. In the wizard, fill in the source and package name where you want to create the Java class.
3. Type in the name of your class, call it "HelloWorld" and select to have a "main" method created. The "New Java Class" wizard is automatically displayed when you click the "Click to Perform" button.

item.title: Edit the main method
item.description: In the "public static void main" method, add the example code found in the help topic associated with this step. The code is under the section "Widget application structure". Once the code is pasted into the editor you will see error markers due to missing import statements. These can be resolved by selecting Source->Organize Imports, when the Organize Imports dialog appears selects the SWT type. Now save your changes. Click the "Click to Complete" button when finished.

item.title: Test your Java Application
item.description: Select your class in the package explorer (the Java tree view on the left of the workbench window in the Java Perspective.). When your HelloWorld class is selected, select Run->Run As->Java Application. A window will open containing the text "Hello World".
